title: Driving lessons - who can teach you

details.description: The rules for driving before you've passed your driving test and got a full licence, who can give you driving lessons, finding a driving instructor, practising with friends and family
details.body:
If you’re paying someone to teach you to drive they must be an approved driving instructor (ADI) or trainee driving instructor.

On average, people who pass their driving test have had 47 hours of driving lessons with a driving instructor and 20 hours of private practice.

You must have a provisional driving licence for Great Britain or Northern Ireland when you’re learning to drive.

Driving instructors

ADIs and trainee driving instructors are regulated by the Driving Standards Agency (DSA). You can find your nearest registered ADIs online.

An ADI displays a green badge on the windscreen, and a trainee driving instructor displays a pink badge.

Driving with friends and relatives

If you want to practise your driving with someone (without paying them) they must:

  • be over 21
  • be qualified to drive the type of vehicle you want to learn in, eg they must have a manual car licence if they’re supervising you in a manual car
  • have had their driving licence for 3 years

If you drive without the right supervision you can be fined up to £1,000 and get 3 to 6 penalty points on your provisional licence.

You can download a driver’s record to track your progress when you’re having private practice.

It’s illegal for the person to use a mobile phone while they are supervising you.

‘L’ and ‘D’ plates

If you’re a learner driver you must put ‘L’ plates on prominent places on the front and back of your vehicle. You can use either ‘L’ or ‘D’ plates in Wales.

Recording your progress

You can download a driver’s record to track your progress with your driving instructor and private practice.

Download ‘Driver’s record for learner drivers’ (PDF, 347KB)
